body: I'd imagine this is an artefact of the design, given that all `ExampleGroup` instances are theoretically nested, but again I'll have to defer to @myronmarston here.
Just to note, RSpec 2 doesn't have this behaviour, there is no `:example_group` key on the top level.

I changed this i b5cd42691c284c488572690a026c94e2ca79be7a.  At the time, I was thinking in terms of the null object pattern.  When a user accesses `:parent_example_group` they expect a hash, and a blank hash represents "no data" just like `nil` does while conforming the interface of the kind of object the caller expects.

You make a good point though.  What do others think?

I'll need to ponder this over lunch. However, I don't see how the code to check if you are at the top level is altered. When you access `metadata[:parent_example_group]` on the top-level, it will be `nil`, since `{}[:parent_example_group]` returns `nil`.

Perhaps I'm missing some aspect of your code that makes a difference here.

> However, I don't see how the code to check if you are at the top level is altered. When you access metadata[:parent_example_group] on the top-level, it will be nil, since {}[:parent_example_group] returns nil.

The difference is that at the top level `group.metadata[:parent_example_group]` returns `{}` rather than `nil`, so you can't use `if group.metadata[:parent_example_group]` as a conditional to see if an example group has a parent or not.

That doesn't seem completely correct. See the output for this on RSpec 3.0.0.rc1:

``` ruby
describe "test parent", a: :b do

  context "testing" do
    it do |ex|
      p ex.metadata[:example_group][:parent_example_group]
      p ex.metadata[:example_group][:parent_example_group][:parent_example_group]
      p ex.metadata[:example_group][:parent_example_group][:parent_example_group][:parent_example_group]
    end
  end
end
# =>
# {:parent_example_group=>{}, ..., :a=>:b}
# {}
# nil
```

Either you'd need to check the grand-parent, or if this is a loop, it'll take one more iteration cycle.

@myronmarston since your initial intent was for the null object pattern, I'm not sure the current implementation fits. You will eventually hit a `nil`. Thoughts?

> That doesn't seem completely correct. See the output for this on RSpec 3.0.0.rc1:

That output is exactly what I'd expect.  What is incorrect about what I said?

> Either you'd need to check the grand-parent, or if this is a loop, it'll take one more iteration cycle.

...or check to see if the `:parent_example_group` return value is an empty hash, as @janko-m mentioned.

> @myronmarston since your initial intent was for the null object pattern, I'm not sure the current implementation fits. You will eventually hit a nil. Thoughts?

Yeah, I'm thinking that it was probably a mistake.  At this point, I think I'd rather it not set the empty hash.  I'm of two minds of whether or not we should change it, though:
- This doesn't exactly fall into the category of "bug fix" changes we're focused on now for 3.0.0 final.
- However, this would be a breaking change post 3.0 and thus this change couldn't be made after 3.0 final comes out until 4.0.  (Unless we want to introduce a config option....and I don't want to go there).
- That said, with 3.0.0.rc1 out for less than a week it's highly unlikely anyone relies upon this behavior yet.  Put another way: right now is the moment when this change will cause the least amount of pain...the longer we wait, the more pain this will cause as the more 3rd-party things may rely on the current behavior.

I _think_ my instinct is that the community would be best served by making this change but I'm on the fence about given the semi-breaking nature of this change I'm on the fence.

Thoughts from @JonRowe / @xaviershay / @samphippen / @soulcutter?
@janko-m What are you traversing up the metadata chain in order to do?

He was fixing VCR to not issue deprecation warnings:

vcr/vcr#414

VCR traverses up the metadata chain when you use its metadata integration...it does that to figure out what the cassette name should be based on the descriptions.

> That output is exactly what I'd expect. What is incorrect about what I said?

I think it was my interpretation of how things were worded. I would have expected `[:parent_example_group]` to always return `{}`.

I agree this is something we should fix before GA. If we don't think it is the behavior we should have, even if we originally intended it fix a specific problem, I think it's still a bug. To me, this is a design flaw of a behavior change. In general, I view design flaws as :bug:s, since they don't fully meet the original requirement. Just my 2cent.
My vote would be to change this back to being `nil`. From a certain perspective it could be considered a regression.
Cool.  I'll take a stab at updating this.
